Not 100 percent confident, just a hunch: The time scale of the evolutionary history of life on Earth relative to the span of the universe and the solar system is sort of indicative that intelligent life is incredibly rare. Let's do some basic math:

First a less convincing point, it took at most 0.8 billion years (a contested number) for the earliest life to form since the earth was born, which factoring the history of the universe of 13.7 billion years, was about 5.8% of the entire length of the universe. While 5.8% doesn't seem that long at first glance, considering many conditions necessarily for life may not exist earlier and that you can only possibly fit 100% / 5.8% = 17.2 of such segments in the universe, it appears pretty long to me.
Secondly, the time it takes for the first intelligent species, (almost certainly) aka humans to emerge from the evolutionary history of life on earth was incredibly long. Life on earth was at least 3.77 billion years old, so it takes about the same length for humans to evolve from the earliest instance of life (human history is so short in billion scale). This is a much larger portion of the universe's span, 3.77 / 13.7 = 27.5%. So more than a quarter of the universe's life it took to incubate life for human to emerge.
Lastly, the window of opportunity is pretty narrow considering the future. Since the condition necessary for life will soon be gone in roughly 1.5 billion years when the sun becomes too hot, that means had humans not exist at present, the life on Earth only have about 1.5 / 3.77 = 40% of time it already spent for the intelligent life to emerge through evolution. In order words, the life on Earth used a sizable portion of its entire possible period of existence for intelligent life to emerge.

The second and third point is more convincing. Let's think about it this way. Getting intelligence life is like rolling a dice or something. Had intelligent life been pretty common and easy to create, then most life in the universe would have taken very little time for intelligent life to emerge, and there's plenty of time left for it to continue to evolve. So either we humans are a rare case of intelligent life, or intelligent life itself is pretty rare, so the only once we get from rolling the dice is something that took so long and barely had anytime left. So in this sense we are extremely lucky. I think the latter scenario is more likely.

There may be some more serious statistics analysis done about it in research papers, but above is my rudimentary thoughts, and that kinda solve the fermi paradox as well. I could be totally wrong though.

Somehow I don't like the fact that science gives up its curiosity so easily at the point of the Big Bang. "What was before that? We don't know, and maybe we never will." Sure, but science is not so yielding in other cases...
Who can check anyway what really happened before that? Scientists should at least come up with a nice understandable, believable model or theory explaining the region beyond that point in spacetime. Instead, it has come up with the same creationist argument as Christianism, or many other religions, except that it excluded the role of a creator. Not very original, imho! It says that spacetime arose from nothing by itself, but it's very much contrary to our experience (and our thinking, too) that time and space can ever start and cease to exist without any cause, or external interference. Self-ceation from nothing is very difficult to explain! If, according to the theory, there were only quantum fluctuations at that point, that means that definitely there was something, and the quantum fluctuations had to have a cause or origina, which means that there had to be something before that, too, if causality was valid at that point.
Whatever the case, science has a great debt to pay back to humankind! Humanity is on its way to get rid of their gods in favour of science, and still, it cannot explain the origin of our Universe.
More seriously, I think that this lack of understanding has to do with the fact that physics and theories are just theories that can never completely describe the real world, which is infinitely more sophisticated.

ooff that was depressing as hell lol. I think a better ending to this video would be that all of this is based on knowledge we have been able to acquire so far (the key terms being SO FAR), otherwise why even bother caring bout what we do in our current time? because if existence would stop forever (which is honestly a questionable statement to make) it would all be meaningless regardless of whether you give it an arbitrary one or not.
Who is to say there is no way to save the universe? who is to say there is no way to traverse into another universe? who is to say that we can't create our own universe? or manipulate it? the possibilities are pretty much endless. We can't be arrogant and say that we already know everything there is to know about existence and then presume we know what happens at "the end", new knowledge can easily shake anything we know about existence, for example knowledge on the origin of the big bang will change the outlet of physicists at a remarkable way, lets be honest, it wouldn't be the first time we got something wrong, hell so far we have made estimate observations of the universe at approximately 46 billion light-years radios from earth, and estimated that its 90 billion light years in diameter from earth, but we don't even concretely KNOW what is within 1 million light years radius from earth, hell some of us are still wondering if there is life on mars, hell we aren't even aware of all species living on earth TODAY. So while it is an interesting theory I have to reject the premise, both on account that I'm not comfortable with it (not gonna lie lol) but more importantly on the basis that knowledge is incomplete, hell FAR from complete I would say.
We could still use our time to pave way to a generation that can possibly evolve to ways we cannot even comprehend or imagine. Imagine in 1 million years our successors develop time traveling? or inter dimensional rifts by some illogical means? truth to the matter is we don't know what will happen, only make predictions based on what we can comprehend. What really matters is what you do with your time right here and now with the little time YOU have left, feel free to make whatever choice you can and know that it has meaning, hell ask that girl or guy out you like, who knows? your union might pave way to something greater, or maybe you will die a lonely virgin who's body will become substance to something that may in some way contribute something to something, even if you or your offspring from many many generations could disappear in the endless sea of time, at the end it definitely was not meaningless. Until we at least figure out how the universe began I refuse to believe that we know what will happen to us, life or even existence.

Heat death is looking to be the most likely theory right now, but it isn't the only one. There is the Big Bounce, where the universe eventually slows down, reverses and then accelerates inwards. Which after a long time leads to the Universe going back to being hot and dense, and leading to another big bang. Which means we might not be the first universe. Or the Big Rip, where dark energy takes over and space keeps accelerating, until the fabric of space time literally tips apart. I don't remember the rest of the consequences, but it's worth researching those, because all of the are pretty speculative. Or at least all have similar believability and chance of happening at this point

Time does not exist in nature. It has never been measured or observed. Whenever you see a mathematical equation with a symbol representing time such as T, simply replace it with N = number of observations of the oscillation of the caesium atom. Or, if you are old school, N = number of observations of the winter solstice. Time was created as a way of comparing the momentum or speed of objects. When a physicist uses an atomic clock they are comparing one motion with a standard motion. Relativity did not make time “real”. It simply made it convenient to think of time as a physical quantity when discussing SR or GR.

Assuming the prehistory information here is accurate, it's interesting to note how little time, relatively speaking, it took for life to emerge on this planet after it stopped just being a glowing-hot ball of slowly coalescing stellar dust.  And it's mind-boggling how long single-celled organisms existed before the current exponential rise in complexity began.  But all that is of course assuming that there isn't a decimal-point screwup in the scientists' calculations, or some explanatory event of which no historical record survives (eg the Von Daniken hypothesis, which I personally doubt, but it does posit a vaguely-plausible reason for this seeming improbability, that one day a bunch of microbes that had never tried to evolve suddenly started getting busy, and now a mere geologic eyeblink later, you get all of this shit).

It's inaccurate to say that all the other human species died out; there's evidence to suggest that several of them were hybridized out of existence by breeding with us.  We have a few strands of Neanderthal DNA in our collective genome even to this day, and there may well have been similar events so far back in our history that literally every now-surviving person has the resulting pre-HSS inheritance, making it impossible to detect as having not originally been part of our Cro-Magnon ancestors.  So really, we didn't kill all the other species, we just fucked them into oblivion so their babies became our hybrid descendants, with their genetic legacy being Homeopathically diluted into nonexistence.  The same thing will likely happen to all currently existing races, unless our global society collapses into a bunch of warring regional tribes again due to some sort of apocalyptic disaster.

I love your videos, but this one is full of so much speculation and things that are just theory's.
The science and history are not sound either and what has been presented as facts, are infact just one of many possibilities of how the formation of earth or the universe came to be.
The same can be said about the future prospects.
Nothing can be presented as absolute unless an experiment is observed from its beginning to its end and run several times to be sure. This is impossible with regards to the life cycle of a star.
You say all stars will eventually burn out.. but what about the formation of brand new ones?
You present evolution as fact, when it isnt.
So few ancient 'Neandathol' skeletons have been discovered too. The difference in shape from a human skeleton could be a result of something else, like birth defects, freaks of nature, mutilation or mutation. If humans lived longer in times past, their skeletons would also look very different after 100s of years of growth in comparison to one that lives less than 100 years.
A global flood or ice age would dramatically alter geological results when calculating the age of anything we find due to the compression.

I do love these videos though but much prefer ones about nature and atoms where we have seen the proven science.

People think 'time' is an aspect of nature, when it is only a construct used to track change. For example, units of time can vary, but the history of change is fixed, since 'change' is the aspect of nature, not time. This means that when people say they want to travel through time, they completely miss the point, and they will fail. What they want to do is go back in CHANGE, not time. For going back in time, you only need to run your timepieces backwards. So the title to the video should be Change: The History and Future of Everything, where units of time are arbitrary.

There is debate about the age of Pyramids and Great Sphinx that is pretty much opened. I wish that Kurzgesagt did an episode about alternative view on Archeology as mind-blowing things are being discovered as we live now. Sphinx has water erosion dating pre 12k BC and relatively newly discovered Göbekli Tepe temples are dated for 10k BC. There is also pyramid dating pre Ice-Age (20 000 years old!) called Gunung Padang in Indonesia, this is huge as "modern" archeology tells us that first civilizations originated around 4000 BC. We might be species with big amnesia and there is a lot of to learn from our past ancestors. There is tons of hard scientific evidence confirming this; I recommend for everyone who is interested in this to listen to people like Randall Carlson, Graham Hancock, Robert Schoch or Anthony John West. It makes be very sad that these people are being labeled as Conspiracy Theorists as we speak now while closed-minded archaeologists like Zahi Hawass are being put on pedestal. This world leading archeologist once said "I don't believe in radar" while being confronted about dating of Göbekli Tepe in Turkey. I recommend video called "Zahi Hawass Storms out of Debate with Graham Hancock before it Begins" that will show you current state of affairs in archeology. Wake up people :)

Turns out he had been born in another town hundreds of miles away but nobody noticed until after his death a journalist did a through search of old registries in Chile. The entire universe will reach maximum entropy and die... but this life is precious so make it count. Logically inconsistent. Even if I don’t make it count the universe will still ultimately end so it won’t matter. Living longer, creating, making scientific discoveries, falling in love... all just pointless prolonging of the inevitable. Once I die I won’t remember anything or be aware of future advancements so they wouldn’t matter from my perspective. Future generations may live with the consequences of our actions today, but eventually they’d die the same as everyone else regardless of their lifespan... and if they are killed in infancy then they don’t have to suffer consequences anyway. Waste implies value, which would ultimately die with the universe. If you don’t believe in an afterlife you should be a nihilist. If not you’re irrational.

Is it bad that even after say, 10 or so videos of Kurzgesagt saying: "You may feel uncomfortable" or "You may be feeling strange right now", I never actually feel any different? The idea of the existence of the universe coming to a halt has little meaning to me or the ideas of what we will achieve. I simply imagine in the back of my mind that one day we will have learnt and accomplished so much that we will be ready to let go or use what knowledge we have left to prevent the end of the universe. Perhaps we'll have found a way to visit other universes in the multiverse, or they'll find us. Or maybe heat death will be proven wrong due to sources of energy re-entering the universe somehow. Maybe we'll take energy from other universes to survive. Maybe wormholes will bring us to the galaxies that left our cluster by the effects of the big bang, who knows and who cares at this rate. I think the thing to focus on is our immediate problems (within 100 generations) such as global warming and mass extinction of animals world wide, etc.

Interesting presentation however you place the historical events (theories) on a linear timeline. With the current advancements of quantum knowledge coupled with our foray into the understanding of the 'multiverse' and dark matter - the static linear timeline becomes warped or skewed like a 3D pretzel.

Time may or may not be linear and whilst it's the basis of most people's life and belief systems it's good to think outside the circle (or square) and perhaps look at life in terms of fractal or perpetual repeating events which are made up of linear segments. This may include the universe expanding whilst contracting and the end of a life cycle can be also interpreted as the beginning of something new and unique.

It's just not as simple as the presentation makes out and we have a lot of data to support quantum mechanics which in many ways fills in the blanks and answers questions of the origin (Big Bang) and end/rebirth of this universe for there are many.

This train of thought coincides with many religions and belief systems but it's all open to personal interpretation !

Living in the present is good advice as you state and ones intentions craft ones path in the tree of life. Good attracts the same, likewise with bad.

History is wonderful to ponder and muse over, what's left of it anyway. So much has been forgotten or lost in interpretation. What we have left, the relics are important and need to be studied with an open mind. 🌝🌚

There are older living people than Celino Jaramillo. Well, allegedly. The issue is what constitutes proof. In most of the world the type of records kept are simply not considered adequate proof, and even today there are people born without any proof of their birth anywhere.  Essentially,  it's impossible to say that this is the oldest person,  but also impossible to say the opposite - not without adjusting what we are willing to accept as proof. To give an example,  I recall a few cases from a few decades ago - a few from rural china - where people had documentation,  but it was so old that the people reviewing the paperwork had never seen it before and assumed at first it was a forgery. Of course k even if they were older I have no way of knowing if any of them are stilp alive. On the flip side,  if we accepted such proof it would be fairly easy to fake.  In any case,  this video could have been clear about that.

Physicist here! Don't be glum - heat death isn't necessarily the end! There's still a possibility that the universe will "snap back" to a singularity, and the cycle will begin anew, and even if this doesn't happen, as time approaches infinity, the odds of vacuum decay (which Kurzgesagt also made a great video on) occurring approaches 1, which means a new pocket universe will be born. So sure, nothing you do now will matter in 10^103 years, no matter how great you are, but not only does this level the playing field for all of us in a way, but we don't have to face the grim thought of endless nothingness.

I naively thought this was actually going to be about time, rather than about history (including the speculative history of the future). However, it managed to entertain me just the same.

One pedantic quibble: I do think it was a little bit jejune to suggest that the year 1 on our now largely standard calendar is set entirely arbitrarily (sure, it doesn't accurately reflect the birth of Jesus of Nazareth, but it was certainly an attempt to do so, and it's hard to tell a coherent story about human history without any reference to religion). This likely doesn't bother too many viewers and I appreciate that it may have been a way to try to circumambulate around any controverted issues related to religion (since, of course, we all know how well that goes on the internet), but still it left me feeling like the video was accommodationist to the point of being slightly intellectually shallow. I had a similar complaint about the suggestion that there may be something (temporally) prior to the big bang - but, I best limit myself to one complaint a day.

Otherwise, as always, fantastic video.

Newton studied time for 30 years, until finally he announced he’d made sense of it. The universe he said was like a giant clock, time kept everything in order.
He had the idea that there was simply one universal absolute time the same for everybody, everywhere, didn’t matter where they were it was the same throughout the universe.
According to Newton time was fixed and it’s flow and pace never varied.
Newton had a dark vision about time. He said time was so fixed, so ordered, that it must have all been planned from the beginning, our future was already decided upon and there was nothing we could do about it.
There was a philosophical downside to Newton’s laws also. The future was pre-determined, we’re nothing but puppets reading from the script, reading from the book of destiny.
We like to think that what we’re going to do tomorrow is undetermined except by what we decide to do but in the Newtonian view our detailed action tomorrow was determined in the beginning of time.?

The answer to what happened before the big bang is that the question is impossible to answer. There couldn't be a "before the big bang" because time and space didn't exist until the big bang. Even saying "until the big bang" does not make sense... because time didn't exist. Nothing existed in a singularity of everything when everything was nothing. The instant the big bang occurred, time started existing. The universe was infinitely big, but still a singularity. Hard to imagine, but it all makes perfect sense somehow.

The first year of the 21st century was 2001, so that kid would be 17 years old by now, at most. Unlike hours, minutes and seconds, which are measuring time from a 0 point, years (and months, weeks and days) are not measuring but counting, not starting on 0 but on 1. If you think about the years b.C. and A.D, and the birth of a child on which this counting system is based, there is little sense on having a year 0. Since this birth starts a year, and therefore ends another, it makes more sense that it divides the years 1 b.C. and 1 A.D. than 1 b.C. and 0 A.D. (or 0 b.C. and 0 A.D., which makes no sense at all).

You can't just say heat death is going to happen... And then add on to say the time is precious. That's contradictory. Life, and everything else, becomes trivial and irrelevant from the moment heat death (or some other possible resulting fate of the universe) is mentioned. By saying that... Means that you acknowledge that existence is meaningless.

You'll eventually die. Your remains will be abandoned on a planet that is doomed to be incinerated. Your memories, and ideals will be forgotten. Everything you're doing has been, and will be pointless. But the present is all that matters? Yes and no. The past already happened. The future already happened. But you'll always live in the present. You'll become weak, and puny, as the ravages of time shred your DNA and everything around you.

Basically. Nothing matters. This applies to you... To me... To everything, and everyone. What happens after? Nothing. This could be the first universe. Second. Third. Tenth. Two Hundredth. Eight Thousandth. Every time a universe exists... New, and self aware beings can exist. Or it's us. We could be that Tenth universe. This is our tenth time living this hell. Then the universe dies. Then another universe exists again. Oh look, the Big Bang. Galaxies. Earth. Dinosaurs. Humans. War. Then after all of those billions of years... Here you are again. Your eleventh self. Twelfth self. Thirteenth. Twentieth. Great. But I don't know that. What I do know is that death... And nonexistence is inevitable. There's no need to waste your time on getting there faster.

I want to say Kurzgesagt is right... That time is precious... But then it would contradict with my argument. Then again... If everything is trivial and irrelevant... Then it's better to be blissfully ignorant of the situation. You could have a couple days, weeks, months, or years left to live. Don't just live for yourself. Live for the future generation. Give them a chance... So that they can do the same for the next generation. Because in the end... Your life is a terminal illness. You're a human. You won't transcend anything. Hurry up while you have time.

Everythign was great until the assumption about how the universe will end.  That's purely just a guess, though certainly a possibility.  To assume that the dynamics of universe will continue as they currently are until the "end of time" is a pretty big assumption to make when we barely understand the universe at all and have really only been studying it from within a small timescale.  Life is sort of a counter point to Entropy, though it does not defeat it as is, however "to preserve itself" is the fundamental motivation... 4 billion years and counting is a feat that some stars never make it to.  Who knows what the future truly holds for either us, the universe, and what role we (or any life, from anywhere) will have billions of years in relationship to the universe with new capabilities and technologies that open the door to endless potential and possibilities.

It's rather likely that our universe has died before but thanks to our buddy quantum physics, it is known that particles randomly pop into existence, then randomly cancel each other out. It is not impossible to assume that when a particle creates itself there is a discrepancy that stops it from being cancelled out or simply the opposite particle doesn't exist means you now have a +1. given enough time and luck (remembering the same could happen with an opposite which would, in turn, cancel out) you could create positive mass out of nothing until it reacts or there is enough of it to create matter or if it goes negative create negative mass (antimatter as far as I would understand). This process would take an incredible amount of time (googolplex zeros) but would be a reasonable explanation to how we could have come to exist and how it is possibly already happened multiple times. You can say 'that is so unlikely it is impossible' and you're right, it is. But given enough time literally nothing is impossible.

I disagree with your end Kurzgesagt. For me, after the last star turning of, there will be no energy anymore in universe, so no reason for expansion continuation. The universe will begin to shrink, to eventually finish in the big crunch. After that, all matter will reorganise in a new universe thru a new big bang.

The Universal Heat death theory is just one of the plausible fates of the universe.
Considering existence as we know it had a *start*, it may very likely have an end, and transformation.
Since energy cannot be created or destroyed, it is just as likely that the remnants of our universe will still have their very weak gravitational waves, and with the lack of any other energy we could very well have all of what is left eventually combine into an incredibly dense single black hole-type event in which when the last bit of "stuff" gets absorbed, a new big bang will occur.
Or, something we can never possibly imagine will occur.
The heat death is just one of an untold number of possible occurrences. I wish the end of the videos "Heat Death" was mentioned as just one possibility rather than the definitive answer to the end of everything.

But, the thing is, we might not die of heat death. We don't know for sure that there aren't other universes. You might say that seems preposterous, but mathematics tells us more.

You see, based on the laws of probability, the universe ends. For every single millimetre outside of the observable universe, there is an incredibly small chance it just stops.
But at the same time, for every single millimetre outside of the core of the earth, there is another incredibly small chance that there is a sort of gateway to another universe exists. This gradually grows smaller as it reaches nearer the surface, then greater as it leaves sea level. This is because we don't know whether we can actually find these portals, and the further away from our notice, the larger the chance (albeit a very small increase). Because the distance between the centre of the Earth to the proposed 'edge' of the universe is stupidly large, there is an above 50% probability that there is a way to get to another universe, if we venture far enough. And that might say that we can create a gateway if there isn't one already. We cannot know how MUCH larger the probability is, because we don't know where this 'edge' is.

But rest assured, there's a large probability that there is a way to escape heat death.

And an even larger probability that if we don't make it, another species will.

TL;DR
Due to the fact that we know nothing, we might not be doomed.

I'm 14, let's start there. For months, I've been trying to fully understand time and the process of evolution. I know the chronological order of things: big bang, sun, earth, life, fish, dinosaurs, explosion, animals, monkeys, humans. But such huge periods of time are too much for me to process. It all happened so slow. And I think I'm somehow refusing the fact that I'm just a simple creature amongst billions of creatures, I don't matter. For this universe, 100 years feels like one minute for a human. I don't want to be forgotten so quickly... I don't want to die, without having seen all the amazing things people will create, without finding out how our world will evolve. This pops in my mind whenever I'm alone, and I just can't get it out of my head. How do I get over this?

A very well researched and edited video as always, love what you're doing, but here are some of the errors I caught:
-I was born on December 6th of 2000, therefore I'm seventeen now and will turn 18 later in the calendar year. At the time of this upload, there was an error where it should've said that anyone born before the 21st century, not the first year.
-When you mention homo sapiens sapiens as a species, that is factually incorrect. homo sapiens is our species, sapiens sapiens is the subspecies with which we share the primary chunk of our genetic information. Small portions of our genetic code were obtained via the assimilation of other homo sapiens subspecies, like homo neanderthalensis and homo rhodesiensis being subsumed into our being, declassifying ourselves as homo sapiens sapiens, and just homo sapiens because of the wide genetic variation and lack of defined sub-special traits.
-you claimed the age of the universe is 13.75 billion years old, while we have two ways of measuring this idea. When we average the two methods to the highest degree of certainty possible, we actuallyget 13.799 (±0.021) billion years, which does not encompass your claim of 13.75 billion years, which should've been rounded to 13.8 for your safety. But the range doesn't inlcude your date, as the range is 13.820 to 13.778 billion years

I have my thoughts about heat death and "forever" death. Well it all has to do with second law of thermodinamics, entropy and so, yet entropy is an probabilistic thing, it talks about the chance of something happening espontaneusly. 2nd law goes something like "entropy in the universe always increase" because it is quite improbable that it goes the other way around, yet not impossible. Now you might say a 1 in a thousands and thousands of trillions chance is pretty much zero but it isn't when you are talkin about infinite time (which forever means). Sooo if we are right about how phisics works, then there isn't such thing as a "heat death", it'd be more like a "heat coma where everything in the universe dissapears during an unimaginable amount of time until it suddenly comes back to life".

'What came before the Big Bang?' doesn't make sense.  It's a wrong question.  Time was created in the Big Bang, and without time there is no ordering of events which could give you the ability to distinguish between 'before' and 'after'.  You can't extend your intuitive sense that time always just 'is' beyond the beginning of time.  Any time you want to deal with the extremities of any idea, you're going to need to be very careful with the exactly precise definitions of what you're dealing with.  And once you do that for time, you realize that asking about 'before' it began simply doesn't make sense.

How did the universe begin? How did time begin? Where did everything used to form the universe come from? Where does the universe end? If you shoot an arrow through space and nothing counter-acts its speed and velocity, will it hit an edge? If there is an edge, doesn't it therefore have another side? I like to think that time works in a cycle just like everything else in life. We used to think the world had an edge just to realize it continues around itself in a spherical fashion. What if time and the universe just wraps around the same way and everything is created the same exact way all over again every time it "ends"? Boom "eternal recurrence" and existential crisis averted. So, if this idea is reasonable in your mind, then you should live your life the way that you will always want to. And don't think it will ever get boring. If "eternal recurrence" is true, then you likely don't remember how your life happened a billion times before. Therefore, it is like a drink that you will forget the taste of as soon as it's gone and it will refill for you to taste for the first time again. Make it a good drink I say then.

technically the year 2000 was the last year of the 20th century.. Although decades and millenniums begin on year ---0 and -000 and end on year ---9 and -999 respectively, for some reason the century is different, as it begins on year --01 and ends on year --00. I know it doesn't really make sense for it to be different from the decade and millennium systems, but that's just how it is. Which means a person who was born in 2000 was still born in the 20th century, although in a different decade and different millennium from someone born in 1999.

What is funny to think about is that every single comment you make on a video, including this one will be gone due to video removal/channel removal/no more YouTube. In fact, every single trace you make; your cells, your fingerprints, the molecules, atoms and even quarks that make up you will someday be all gone. Don't feel too unoptimistic, because this happens in the course of a long, long time.

Luckily, you have a 1/100 chance of there being a new universe that is actually habitable.
So, if we move to another universe, technology will have to be so advanced by then that we can go over the speed of light. Luckily, we have lots of time for that. Over 1 trillion years to be exact. If we can accomplish that, there's still another barrier we have to pass. Luck. We have to know if the universe we are travelling to is actually habitable. Well, it has to be an exact replicate of our universe in the same time we left off of our last red dwarf star. We also need all the elements in the periodic table the same. Don't forget to mention that it could take a long, long time. We would have to travel light-years of space. One notable thing is that there is no dark matter, so it won't make it longer. So we'll have a slim, slim chance of survival. But remember, our species would have lived a long, long time by then.

Hey kurzgesagt! Hate to be ‘that guy’ but in the interest of fake news, do your bar charts observe the area rule?

I mean: when you show one length of time in proportion to another, is the areas of the bars in proportion as well as the lengths.

If the areas aren’t in proportion, it can be misleading and give people the wrong idea. A lot places deliberately break the area rule to make the news/statistics look more favourable.

Sigh. Nothing happened before the Big Bang. Nothing has to happen before the Big Bang. In fact, you could say we never actually existed? Virtual particles can appear out of nothing and then disappear. This means that our Universe could also have appeared out of nothing and disappeared. We aren't breaking any laws or stealing anything from the Universe.

Picture this, I'll loan you a $1 for a few Quintilian years. You can't earn any money nor can you use the money because you have to give it back. In the end, what you actually own is still $0. You could say that we never even existed at all.

We are merely virtual

Oh and since this is the case, due to the Poincaré recurrence theorem, another Universe can appear again.

Before the universe becomes no more, would it be possible for civilizations to make artificial stars etc? Maybe the universe wont actually end from heat death.

Good chance Heat Death won't be the end.

Matter still exists in Heat Death.
Now let's make a grid of matter below.

MMMMM
MMMMM
MMMMM
MMMMM
MMMMM

Heat Death looks like this:

M M M M M
M M M M M
M M M M M
M M M M M
M M M M M

Now gravity exists... always.
Upon heatdeath, those subatomic particles are going to head to areas that have higher density.
But where is higher density? In the middle.
If we go to one line:

M M M M M

We see that for the M on the left, it is getting pulled to the right by 4 M's.
For the M on the right, it is getting pulled to the left by 4 M's.
For the M in the middle, it is getting pulled 2 to the left, and 2 to the right, it stays where it is.

Upon reaching Heat Death, and the universe reaching equilibrium, there will be no energy moving any of the matter.
Only gravity.
Gravity will pull it all back together.
This in turn will cause temperature to rise as the SaPs hit each other and fuse.

MMMMM
MMMMM
MMMMM
MMMMM
MMMMM

We can't know what will result.
Stars? Black holes? Something new?
We also can't know how long it would take for everything to come back together. It could take just as long as it did to reach Heat Death initially.

There's also theories that this could be a Big Crunch Big Bang cycle.
I say maybe, but I like combining it with the inside a black hole theory.
Everything comes back together, and the big bang is actually the singularity that everything comes in from, making the universe itself a black hole, within infinite black holes.

But back on topic.

Chances are, the universe doesn't end at Heat Death.

Correct me if i'm wrong, but the heat death of the universe is 600 billion years away. And, in the last 200,000 years humans have gone from animals to a planet wide, soon to be interplanetary society. Is it not forseeable, that in time, we could have the technology to stop the heat death of the universe, at least in one place. I know that seems to be an impossible task now, but it would seem possible that if we can manage to survive we could continue to keep at least one star system functioning indefinitely, provided the technology exists. Or for another example, in a billion years it could very well be possible to alter the orbit of Earth, meaning that we could move the planet into the suns new habitable zone so that life could still thrive on Earth. No one really knows what is possible in the long run, and humans certainly have along way to go, but if we could cross the major barriers that stand in the way of potential intergalactic growth, I'm almost certain that we could figure out a way to contine life in the universe on one level or another with 600 billion years to figure ourselves out. Just a thought.

I wonder to what extent calenders influence human thinking. The other day I was learning about the traditional Chinese method of counting years and (on the whole) they didn't use consecutive years from a defined point - the year was generally given in terms of 'x' years after the start of the current Emperor's reign and/or in terms of 60 year cycles based partially on the Chinese Zodiac.

As a result, I can't help but wonder how people in Ancient China perceived long stretches of time. In the West (or any of the other cultures that had a defined start year to their calender, which I think was pretty common) it's fairly easy to put Ancient Mesopotamians, Greeks, Romans, Germanic Invasions (Anglo-Saxons for Brits), Middle Ages...etc. on a mental timeline, because most people are aware of rough cronological periods for these things. I can't imagine how I would make sense of history without a fixed reference point, especially when it comes events not taking place in the same place, but then the Western calender is all I've ever really known.

No, the first year of the 21st century was 2001. We never counted the year 0, so the 100th year was the year 100. In other words, years 1-100 were the 1st century, years 101-200 were the second, etc. 1801-1900 was the 19th century, 1901-2000 was the 20th century.

That being said, the 1900's ended in 1999, however, the 1900's do not equal the 20th century.

Although it's little more than a minor technical issue.

What a lovely day to have an existential crisis ...

Scary knowing we’re not here forever. We’re just a little dot on the timeline. Insignificant you could say. All the time that’s passed and so many things that have progressed yet we only live not a even a fraction of a fraction of it. At moments I get caught up thinking that life seems to be moving to slow, but in reality it’s going faster than anyone can imagine. So many questions. Are we really all here by the name of science or is there something beyond science that has created this unfathomable fabric of space and time? I hope when I die I can at least have this question answered. Reality as we know it is insane to me. Sometimes I catch myself observing something so simple such as a bird observing its surroundings while standing on a power line or a tree and I think to myself how can this be? What is consciousness and why am I allowed to have it? Why does this language that we speak with such memory and confidence convey my thoughts in a way that question life and existence as we know it? Amazing nonetheless. But so bizarre and mysterious. So much more to say but scrambled in endless confusing thoughts.

Enjoyed the vid except for one part. You say we don't know what came before the Big Bang and maybe never will. While i understand the limit of knowledge when there is insufficient data theres actually arguments out there that it might be impossible for there to be "Something" before the Big Bang because Spacetime might just shift in size compressing and expanding constantly.

The notion of "before the Big Bang" really makes comparatively little sense. Time (and causality, for that matter) are features of our universe - there was no "before" the the Big Bang, because there was no *time*. Concepts like before and after can only exist in a world where time exists, though.
Much the same with the cause of the Big Bang: since causality is only a feature of our universe, it may not make sense to ask what caused it to exist. Sure, both causality and time may have been features of what was there before, if there was anything at all, but we don't know that, and may never do.

The person you gave as the oldest person is waaay out of date now. Being as it changes every 6 months or so you should have probably just put in the oldest person ever, who was 122.

For the future section, you went straight to a billion years. There are a number of things you could have put before and around then. For example, the last total eclipse on earth, triton colliding with neptune, and phobos with mars, andromeda colliding with the milky way, moores law induced singularity, a few climate change predictions etc. going straight to a billion after all the effort in the past makes it feel a bit rushed!

also for the future section, you stopped giving people dates of things which cover a huge range of even log(time). Also, at eventual heat death it is the end of time (no flow of entropy), until quantum fluctuations bring forth a new universe at the poincare recurrence time (assuming the universe doesn't go anywhere in the meantime).

There are many particles, atoms, molecules, planets, galaxies and so on and so forth. Nothing comes in ones in nature. Well, when humans start to build huge megastructures in space we can do some pretty crazy things. For example we can starlift most of the hydrogen and all of the metals and helium out of the sun till it becomes a fully convective red dwarf which burns hydrogen really slowly. And then trickle the hydrogen we took out back into the star and remove the new larger elements formed. If we do his we can extend the suns remaining lifespan from 5 billion years to 75 trillion years.

And before you say “that will kill all life in earth” well, you can always move the earth closer to the sun and use giant orbital mirrors larger than planets to focus more of its light down onto the earth to keep us nice and warm.

And we can also dismantle some larger stars to use as fuel for many red dwarfs, so the stellar period of the universe could last a hell of a lot longer than 100 trillion years, possibly even into the quadrillions depending on how many stars we take apart.
